text: Pushback is, I couldn't imagine a word more viscerally that makes you feel like you're sort of physically going against what somebody else wants, and it gears people into a mindset of then, well, how should I push back. It starts from a place of I need to disagree, I need to say no. It's a very negative mindset, purely based on the word that has come to label a behavior that alternatively could be about how do I shift the direction on something, or how do I help the business actually succeed when I disagree with somebody about something, and that's a very different mindset.
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason about how to effectively push back on CEOs and founders when disagreeing with their decisions. Jason argues that the term 'pushback' itself creates a problematic framing because it sets up an adversarial mindset focused on disagreement and saying no, when the real goal should be helping the business succeed through constructive redirection.
text_ko: 푸시백(pushback)이라는 말만큼 사람들로 하여금 '상대가 원하는 것에 그냥 몸으로 맞서는 느낌'을 주는 단어는 상상하기 어려워요. 그 말 자체가 사람들을 '그럼 어떻게 푸시백해야 하지?'라는 마인드셋(mindset)으로 몰아넣죠. 즉 처음부터 '반대해야 해, 아니라고 말해야 해'라는 출발점에서 시작하는 아주 부정적인 사고방식이에요. 그런데 사실 그 단어로 규정된 행동은 달리 보면 '어떻게 방향을 바꿀 수 있을까'나 '누군가와 의견이 다를 때 어떻게 하면 비즈니스가 실제로 성공하도록 도울 수 있을까' 같은 얘기일 수도 있어요. 그건 완전히 다른 마인드셋이에요.
text_zh: Pushback这个词，我想不出还有什么词能让人这么强烈地感觉到你在跟别人硬碰硬，而且一听到这个词，大家就会想"那我该怎么怼回去"。一开始就是抱着"我得反对，我得说不"的心态。这完全就是个负面思维，就因为用了这么个词来形容一种行为。其实换个角度想，这种行为也可以是"我怎么调整一下方向"，或者"当我跟别人意见不一致的时候，怎么帮公司真正做成事"，这样想就完全不一样了。
text_es: La resistencia o el "pushback", no se me ocurre una palabra que te haga sentir más visceralmente que estás yendo físicamente en contra de lo que otra persona quiere, y eso mete a la gente en una mentalidad de "bueno, ¿cómo debería resistirme?". Parte de un lugar de "necesito estar en desacuerdo, necesito decir que no". Es una mentalidad muy negativa, basada puramente en la palabra que ha llegado a etiquetar un comportamiento que, por el contrario, podría ser más bien "¿cómo redirijo algo?" o "¿cómo ayudo realmente al negocio a tener éxito cuando no estoy de acuerdo con alguien sobre algo?", y esa es una mentalidad muy diferente.

text: I mean, I think the biggest surprise to me, despite what we were just talking about, was how big some products have gotten without kind of the traditional either product manager role or without the playbooks that we're so used to from the last 20 years of the internet. And so, for example, Uniswap has done more daily volume on certain days than Coinbase, and Uniswap is about a hundred people versus 5,000-plus at Coinbase, right? So, that's astounding to me.
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason what has surprised him most about working as a PM in Web3. Jason explains that he's been amazed by how large Web3 products have grown without traditional product management roles or established internet playbooks. He uses Uniswap as an example - a decentralized exchange that sometimes processes more daily trading volume than Coinbase despite having only 100 employees compared to Coinbase's 5,000+ workforce.
vocabulary_highlights: the playbooks that we're so used to
text_ko: 제 생각엔, 방금 얘기한 것과는 별개로 가장 놀라웠던 건 전통적인 제품 관리자 역할(product manager role)이나 지난 20년간 인터넷 시대에 우리가 익숙해진 플레이북(playbooks) 없이도 어떤 제품들이 이렇게 커졌다는 점이에요. 예를 들어 어떤 날에는 유니스왑(Uniswap)이 코인베이스(Coinbase)보다 하루 거래량(daily volume)이 더 많았고, 유니스왑은 인원이 약 100명인 반면 코인베이스는 5,000명 이상이잖아요. 그게 정말 놀랍더라고요.
text_zh: 我觉得最让我意外的是，尽管我们刚才说了那些，但有些产品居然能做得这么大，完全没有传统的产品经理(product manager)角色，也没有用我们过去20年互联网时代那套成熟的打法。比如说，Uniswap某些天的日交易量甚至超过了Coinbase，但Uniswap才100来个人，Coinbase可是5000多人的团队，对吧？这真的太令人震惊了。
text_es: Mira, creo que lo que más me sorprendió, a pesar de lo que acabamos de hablar, fue ver qué tan grandes se han vuelto algunos productos sin tener ese rol tradicional de product manager o sin los manuales (playbooks) a los que nos acostumbramos en estos últimos 20 años de internet. Por ejemplo, Uniswap ha manejado más volumen diario que Coinbase en ciertos días, y Uniswap tiene como cien personas comparado con las más de 5,000 de Coinbase, ¿no? Eso me parece impresionante.

text: I think it's all about a focus on progress and moving forward. We saw this at Airbnb when the business had a draw down in revenue, and I know you'd covered this with Sanchan recently, right? It was 85, 90% revenue and you didn't know when it was going to turn around, right? It's not just like, 'Oh yeah, this will come back in six months and we can just keep plowing forward.' But I think what worked was making progress and actually focusing on product and your customers, and ultimately if you hire the right people who are motivated for the right reasons, I think that recipe keeps people highly motivated and highly effective at building for when things do eventually turn around.
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason how he's managed to keep teams focused and maintain morale during the recent crypto winter while working in Web3. Jason explains that the key to maintaining morale during difficult periods is making tangible progress rather than relying on speeches or external motivators. He references how Airbnb maintained team effectiveness during COVID when they lost 85-90% of their revenue by continuing to focus on product development and customer needs.
text_ko: 진짜 중요한 건 지속적인 발전과 앞으로 나아가는 거라고 생각해요. Airbnb에서도 매출이 줄어들었을 때 그런 걸 경험했죠. 최근에 산찬이랑 이 얘기 나눴던 거 아시죠? 매출이 85%, 90%까지 떨어졌고, 언제 회복될지 전혀 알 수 없었어요. 단순히 '아, 6개월 후에 돌아올 거니까 그냥 계속 밀고 나가면 돼' 이런 게 아니었죠. 하지만 중요한 건 발전을 이루고, 제품과 고객에 집중하는 거였어요. 그리고 결국 올바른 이유로 동기부여가 된 사람들을 채용하면, 그런 조합이 사람들을 매우 동기부여하고 효과적으로 만들어서 상황이 좋아질 때를 대비할 수 있게 해준다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得关键就是要专注于进步，不断往前走。你看Airbnb那会儿营收大跌的时候就是这样，我知道你最近跟三展也聊过这事儿，对吧？当时收入掉了85%、90%，完全不知道什么时候能回转，对不对？这不是说"哦没事，六个月后就能好转，我们继续埋头干就行了"那么简单。但我觉得有效的做法就是持续取得进展，真正把重心放在产品和客户身上。最终如果你招到了对的人，他们的动机也是对的，我觉得这个配方就能让大家保持很高的积极性和执行力，为最终的回转做好准备。
text_es: Creo que todo se trata de enfocarse en el progreso y seguir adelante. Lo vimos en Airbnb cuando el negocio tuvo una caída fuerte en ingresos, y sé que hablaste de esto con Sanchan hace poco, ¿verdad? Fue una caída del 85, 90% de los ingresos y no sabías cuándo se iba a recuperar, ¿no? No era como decir 'Ah sí, esto se va a recuperar en seis meses y podemos seguir adelante como si nada.' Pero creo que lo que funcionó fue hacer progreso real y enfocarse de verdad en el producto y en tus clientes, y al final del día, si contratas a las personas correctas que están motivadas por las razones correctas, creo que esa fórmula mantiene a la gente súper motivada y súper efectiva construyendo para cuando las cosas eventualmente se recuperen.

text: I think Amazon was a place where you couldn't divorce business and product. You couldn't be a product manager without thinking about revenue growth, without thinking about go to market, and I really like that because as a startup founder doing product in a bigger company, it gave me the chance to exercise a lot of those skills.
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason which of the major companies he's worked at (Yammer, Microsoft, Amazon, Airbnb) has most influenced his approach to product management. Jason explains that Amazon had the biggest impact because it required PMs to integrate business thinking with product decisions. Unlike companies known for specific cultures (Google for engineering, Facebook for product), Amazon demanded that product managers consider revenue growth and go-to-market strategy as core responsibilities.
vocabulary_highlights: exercise a lot of those skills
text_ko: 아마존은 비즈니스와 제품을 떼어놓을 수 없는 곳이었어요. 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)라면 매출 성장(revenue growth)이나 출시 전략(go-to-market)을 고려하지 않고는 일할 수 없었어요. 저는 그런 점이 정말 좋았어요. 스타트업 창업자(startup founder)로서 더 큰 회사에서 제품을 다루며 그런 역량들을 많이 써볼 수 있었거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得在亚马逊，业务和产品是分不开的。你做产品经理不可能不考虑收入增长，不可能不想着怎么推向市场(go to market)，我特别喜欢这一点，因为作为一个创业者在大公司里做产品，这让我有机会锻炼了很多这方面的能力。
text_es: Creo que Amazon era un lugar donde no podías separar el negocio del producto. No podías ser product manager sin pensar en el crecimiento de ingresos, sin pensar en la estrategia de salida al mercado (go to market), y eso me gustaba mucho porque como fundador de startup haciendo producto en una empresa más grande, me daba la oportunidad de poner en práctica todas esas habilidades.

text: I think the working backwards process of establishing the long-term goal using a mechanism like a press release and the FAQs where every word matters, and even the FAQs, for what it's worth, there's a section for external FAQs that you would include for example as an appendix, but also internal FAQs that are meant to de-risk launch or raise the elephant in the room or dogs not barking as Amazon likes to call it often.
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason about concrete processes or tactics he learned from working at major companies. Jason describes Amazon's 'working backwards' process, which involves writing a press release and FAQ document before building a product. The press release forces clarity about the end goal, while the FAQ section addresses both external customer questions and internal concerns that could derisk the launch.
vocabulary_highlights: raise the elephant in the room
text_ko: 장기 목표를 설정할 때, 보도자료(press release)와 자주 묻는 질문(FAQs) 같은 방식을 활용해 뒤에서부터 작업하는 과정이 중요해요. 모든 단어가 중요하니까요. 외부 FAQ 섹션을 부록으로 포함할 수도 있고, 내부 FAQ는 출시 리스크를 줄이거나 문제를 미리 짚어보는 데 도움이 돼요. 아마존에서 자주 언급하는 '개가 짖지 않는 것(dogs not barking)'을 다루는 것도 포함되죠.
text_zh: 我觉得这种倒推的工作方式挺好的，就是先定下长远目标，然后用新闻稿(press release)和问答(FAQ)这些工具来梳理，每个字都很重要。说到问答部分，其实还挺有意思的，有对外的问答可以放在附录里，也有内部问答，主要是为了降低发布风险，或者把那些大家心照不宣的问题摆到台面上说清楚，亚马逊经常叫这个"不叫的狗"(dogs not barking)。
text_es: Creo que el proceso de trabajar hacia atrás, estableciendo la meta a largo plazo usando un mecanismo como un comunicado de prensa y las preguntas frecuentes donde cada palabra cuenta, y hasta en las FAQs, por cierto, hay una sección para FAQs externas que incluirías como un anexo, por ejemplo, pero también FAQs internas que están pensadas para reducir el riesgo del lanzamiento o sacar a la luz el elefante en la habitación o "perros que no ladran" (dogs not barking) como le gusta decir a Amazon.

text: I think nothing is above them, they're in the details, and they adapt to new information and new situations. That's what I've seen the most that I've appreciated in the best leaders that I've gotten to either observe or work closely with.
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason what he's learned about effective leadership from watching leaders at companies like Amazon, Airbnb, and others. Jason identifies three key traits he's observed in the best leaders: they don't consider any task beneath them (humility), they stay involved in detailed decisions rather than delegating everything, and they adapt their approach based on new information and changing circumstances rather than rigidly sticking to past playbooks.
text_ko: 저는 그분들이 잘난 체하지 않고 세부사항(details)까지 직접 챙기며, 새로운 정보(new information)와 새로운 상황(new situations)에 맞춰 잘 적응하는 모습을 가장 높이 평가했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得没有什么事情是他们不愿意亲自去做的，他们特别关注细节，而且能够根据新信息和新情况灵活调整。这是我在那些最优秀的领导者身上看到的最让我佩服的品质，不管是我观察到的还是跟我密切合作过的。
text_es: Creo que nada se les escapa, se fijan en los detalles, y se adaptan a información nueva y situaciones nuevas. Eso es lo que más he visto y valorado en los mejores líderes que he podido observar o con los que he trabajado de cerca.

text: There's the framework I like is ladder versus map, and I think that you can be either person that any point in your life. Sometimes there's a bit of a set mindset that somebody might have one way or another, but I like ladder versus map. Ladder is about moving up. It's more influence, more power, a higher title, things like this, whereas map is I just want to go wherever's interesting, right?
speaker: Jason Shah
context: Lenny asks Jason about his approach to career development, noting that Jason seems to follow his interests rather than climbing a traditional career ladder. Jason explains his 'ladder versus map' framework for thinking about careers. The ladder approach focuses on moving up hierarchically with more influence, power, and higher titles, while the map approach prioritizes following interesting opportunities regardless of traditional progression.
text_ko: 제가 좋아하는 프레임워크는 사다리(ladder) 대 지도(map)예요. 인생의 어느 시점에든 누구나 두 유형 중 하나일 수 있고, 사람들 중에는 한쪽으로 고정돼 있다고 보는 경우도 있지만 저는 사다리 대 지도 구분이 마음에 들어요. 사다리는 위로 올라가는 거고, 영향력이나 권한, 더 높은 직함 같은 걸 얻는 쪽이에요. 반면 지도는 그냥 흥미로운 곳이면 어디든 가보고 싶어하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我很喜欢一个框架，叫做"阶梯型"对"地图型"，我觉得人在不同阶段可能是不同的类型。虽然有些人可能有固定的思维模式，但我还是喜欢用阶梯对地图这个概念。阶梯型就是往上爬，要更大的影响力、更多权力、更高的职位，这些东西。而地图型呢，就是哪里有意思我就去哪里，对吧？
text_es: Hay un esquema que me gusta mucho que es el de escalera versus mapa, y creo que puedes ser cualquiera de los dos en cualquier momento de tu vida. A veces hay gente que tiene una mentalidad más fija hacia un lado o el otro, pero a mí me gusta esta idea de escalera versus mapa. La escalera se trata de subir - más influencia, más poder, un puesto más alto, ese tipo de cosas. Mientras que el mapa es más como "yo solo quiero ir a donde sea interesante", ¿no?
